title: tailor "borowed value does not live long enough" to temporaries

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

body:
I recently encountered this error message (the relevant code is in the error):

```
error: borrowed value does not live long enough
   --> src/main.rs:109:30
    |
109 |             let mut stderr = io::stderr().lock();
    |                              ^^^^^^^^^^^^       - borrowed value only valid until here
    |                              |
    |                              does not live long enough
...
114 |         }
    |         - borrowed value must be valid until here
    |
help: consider using a `let` binding to increase its lifetime
   --> src/main.rs:109:13
    |
109 |             let mut stderr = io::stderr().lock();
    |             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

error: aborting due to previous error
```

This is great (much better than it used to be) but I feel like could be better still. Some observations:
- the "help" snippet is distracting and kind of confusing; I expect it to reflect the change it is suggesting, but it does not
- we could make the labels explain the fact that this is a temporary value

I'm thinking of something like this:

```
error: temporary value does not live long enough
   --> src/main.rs:109:30
    |
109 |             let mut stderr = io::stderr().lock();
    |                              ^^^^^^^^^^^^       - temporary goes out of scope at end of statement
    |                              |
    |                              temporary created here
...
114 |         }
    |         - reference to temporary goes out of scope here
    |
```

We'd have to be a bit careful though; e.g. saying things like "at end of statement" would require us to check that this is indeed a temporary that only lasts for a single statement, but we can do that.

cc @jonathandturner
